intro: Viola communis, commonly known as the common violet, is a herbaceous perennial plant belonging to the Violaceae family. It is characterized by its heart-shaped leaves and clusters of delicate, five-petaled flowers that range in color from purple to white. The plant typically grows to a height of 10–30 centimeters and thrives in moist, well-drained soils. It is native to temperate regions of Europe, Asia, and North America. Viola communis is often found in woodlands, meadows, and along stream banks, where it plays a role in supporting pollinators like bees and butterflies.
